posts.name: Riley Orange-Juice
posts.cooked:
Hello fellows,

Our team has a very big problem. We have noclue how to start coding our swerve drive. We have very strange and outdated modules with one neo and one pg-motor. The pg-motor has a quadrature encoder connected to a breakout board to a spark max. Unfortunatly, there is little to no documentation on these modules. So help would be most useful.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Given the mention of the PG71, I’m assuming these modules are the AndyMark Swerve & Steer.  All the info you should need can be found on the product page here: Swerve & Steer - AndyMark, Inc .  The gear ratios, built-in encoder CPR, etc are all listed there.

There’s also a link to a CD thread where code samples are provided, though I might look at one of the other (more recent/updated) swerve starter templates out there and simply use the numbers on that page to make it work.

posts.name: Dainen griffes
posts.cooked: same team here. Our issue is that our pg71 motors are not all spinning at the same speed, this is a problem for obvious reasons. we cant find out how to get them all spinning together

posts.name: Fritz G
posts.cooked:
Do you have any code written so far that you could share? It may be worth quickly running something that resets all the motor controllers to factory default and just sets power to 100% on all azimuth motors to rule out any mechanical issues.

My general recommendation for a situation like this is probably recommend YAGSL (check out the JSON config generator here: YAGSL Tuning Webpage ) because once you get it configured to your hardware, all the high level stuff (path planning, etc.) should match what any other team using yagsl would use.

You also have the option of looking for other teams running swerve and steer modules (they’re rare but not completely nonexistent) and using their code as reference.

I think the provided andymark code is labview only, and is probably old enough that it isn’t good for much beyond maybe as a reference.

link_counts.title: GitHub - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL: Yet Another General Swerve Library

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: 100 uses AM modules for practice.  We found it helpful to work from the bottom up, make sure lower layers are working correctly before moving to higher ones.  So for example start by running each of the motors individually and measure the achieved speed using the available encoders.  We also found it much simpler to start with an absolute encoder on the steering (the modules are designed for the MA-3 encoder), thus avoiding the quadrature encoder, Sparkmax encoder input etc.

posts.name: Dainen griffes
Dainen griffes
posts.cooked: Could you possibly lend us your code for the swerve and steer?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
well, everything we do is public, and anyone is welcome to use it, see GitHub - Team100/main2023: Pull requests to main only, do not commit directly here. .

our code is no longer very easy to understand, though, it supports several different robot configurations in a single codebase, and has a bunch of structure that you’ll have to read through to figure out what it’s doing.

we started with the WPILib SwerveControllerCommand example, which I would suggest would be a better starting point for you.
